text: now biscuits they can be a little tricky
and you might be a little bit nervous
when attempting to make them but today
I'm going to share with you an easier
way to make biscuits I'm going to show
you how to make drop biscuits the
kissing cousin of the classic roll and
cut biscuit they're really easy to do
and honestly guys if you master this
recipe you can make this every single
morning for a delicious egg sandwich or
as an accompaniment for your dinner
table so it's really simple two cups of
all-purpose flour
in a large bowl to that I'm going to add
the leavening agents that's two
teaspoons of baking powder now remember
guys baking powder is usually sold as
double acting baking powder and what
that means is it reacts with a liquid
that's the first time it reacts and the
second time or the double time is when
it comes in contact with heat so in the
oven so two teaspoons of baking powder
here a half a teaspoon of baking soda
this will again react with the acidic
buttermilk that we're going to add so
that's going to encourage it to leaven
I'm going to add a little bit of sugar
this is one tablespoon of granulated
sugar and a half a teaspoon
of course kosher salt now today I'm
making savory drop biscuits but you
could certainly make sweet drop biscuits
if you wanted to serve them with butter
and jam that would be great a little bit
of cayenne pepper for some spice so
whisk these spices and the leavening all
together make sure it's evenly
distributed and now as with regular
biscuits I'm going to cut in the fat so
here I have six tablespoons of unsalted
butter this is well chilled and cut into
small cubes now you could certainly use
one of these pastry cutters here this
breaks up the butter into small sized
pieces but I like to just use my hands
now you want to make sure if you're
using your hands or that you work
quickly because you don't want to melt
the butter you just want to break it up
with the flour until little pea-sized
pieces remain this is what is going to
create those wonderful flaky layers
because the little tiny pieces of butter
that are in the biscuit what they do in
the oven is they melt down they create
steam which creates little pockets of
air
that gives you the flakiness in your
biscuit so this shouldn't take too too
long here so this looks good you can see
the flour has kind of moistened up a
little bit with the butter it almost
looks like coarse cornmeal with
pea-sized pieces of fat so this looks
nice and now I'm going to add the cheese
so I have 8 ounces of cheddar cheese
here this is a sharp cheddar cheese so
that's really maximum flavor you could
also use a really great Gruyere cheese
that would be wonderful in this as well
stir this together and add in 3
tablespoons of chopped chives now you
could use chopped dill if you'd like so
once the cheese is kind of evenly
incorporated I'm going to add my
buttermilk right into the center of the
bowl so kind of create a well add your
buttermilk this is 1 in 1/3 cup of
buttermilk make sure before you measure
out your buttermilk that you shake it
sometimes it has a tendency to separate
and now you just want to bring this
together just until everything is
incorporated do not over mix this
because what will happen is you'll end
up with a really tough biscuit so be
gentle here so this is just incorporated
now pre-heat your oven to 425 degrees
I'm going to use an ice cream scoop here
you know this is one of my favorite
tools I love to use it to portion things
out and you need about a quarter of a
cup of the batter now the beauty here
with drop biscuits is that you don't
have to cut these into perfectly browned
bits or perfectly square bites you can
really just kind of use two spoons even
you don't even have to use this ice
cream scoop but you want to be careful
here don't compact the dough don't press
it into the cup you really want these to
remain very nice and light so space them
out you want them about two inches apart
because these will grow and puff so now
again these go right into the oven 425
degrees for about 12 minutes you want to
rotate them halfway through the baking
process until they're nice and golden
brown
so these savory drop biscuits are best
hot out of the oven I would encourage
you to kind of gild the lily here with a
little bit of softened
and there you go an amazing biscuit
recipe that will probably take you half
the time as those conventional biscuits
enjoy guys
[Music]
you
